question: Colipase is an enzyme found in--------?
exp: Pancreatic juice contains lipase, colipase, phospholipase A & B Colipase: Facilitates the action of lipase Prevents inactivation of lipase by bile salts SALIVA: 2 types of secretion 1. Serous: contains ptyalin (a amylase ) - digest carbs 2. Mucus: contains mucin - for lubrication & protection STOMACH: Mucus neck cells - secrete mucus Peptic/chief cells - Pepsinogen Parietal / oxyntic - HCL, intrinsic factor Pyloric glands - gastrin PANCREATIC JUICE: For protein: trypsin, chymotrypsin, carboxypolypeptidase Carbohydrates: pancreatic amylase Fat: pancreatic lipase, cholesterol esterase, phospholipase BILE: composition: Liver Bile Gallbladder Bile Water 97. 5 g/dl 92 g/dl Bile salts 1. 1 g/dl 6 g/dl Bilirubin 0. 04 g/dl 0. 3 g/dl Cholesterol 0. 1 g/dl 0. 3 to 0. 9 g/dl Fatty acids 0. 12 g/dl 0. 3 to 1. 2 g/dl Lecithin 0. 04 g/dl 0. 3 g/dl Na+ 145. 04 m. Eq/L 130 m. Eq/L K+ 5 m. Eq/L 12 m. Eq/L Ca++ 5 m. Eq/L 23 m. Eq/L CI- 100 m. Eq/L 25 m. Eq/L HCO3- 28 m. Eq/L 10 m. Eq/L

question: Which of these is true about SGLT1?
exp: Secondary active transpo of glucose in intestine SGLT Transpoers Substance Site of distribution SGLT 1 Glucose, galactose Intestine, trachea, kidney, hea, brain, testis, prostate SGLT 2 Glucose Kidney, brain, liver, thyroid, muscle, hea SGLT 3 Glucose Intestine, testis, uterus, lung, brain, thyroid SGLT 4 Glucose, mannose Intestine, kidney, liver, brain SGLT 5 Glucose, galactose Kidney SGLT 6 D-chiro inositol Brain, kidney, intestine
opa: Secondary active transpo of glucose in brain
opb: Secondary active transpo of glucose in intestine
opc: Secondary active transpo of glucose in rods and cones
opd: Secondary active transpo of glucose in prostate

question: Vitamin K leads to?
exp: Vitamin K leads to g-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues to clotting factor 2, 7, 9 and 10 Vitamin K is essential for adding carboxyl group to glutamic acid residues on 5 impoant clotting factors 1. Prothrombin (II) 2. Factor VII 3. Factor IX 4. Factor X 5. Protein C
opa: g-carboxylation of aspaic acid residues to clotting factor 2, 7, 9 and 10
opb: b-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues to clotting factor 2, 7, 9 and 10
opc: alpha - carboxylation of asparatic acid residues to clotting factor 2, 7, 9 and 10
opd: g-carboxylation of glutamic acid residues to clotting factor 2, 7, 9 and 10

question: Which of the following ion plays role in exocytosis?
exp: Exocytosis For exocytosis to occur, the vesicle containing neurotransmitter must fuse with pre-synaptic membrane - Vesicle membrane is negatively changed & also the cell is negatively charged. Therefore for this fusion to occur a bridge should be formed & a cation can form this bridges. that cation is Ca2+ - Exocytosis, in most cases, is stimulated by the entry of calcium ions into the cell: Calcium ions interact with vesicular membrane in some way that is not understood and its fusion with the cell membrane followed by exocytosis - That is opening of the membrane's outer surface and extrusion of its contents outside the cell.
